page.title: 07RAMBLES: ACTON/LAVENHAM AREA
page.content: The boulder clay supports a typical neutral soil vegetation. In addition the presence of chalk particles allows such calcicolous plants as Traveller's Joy and Dogwood to thrive. Primroses and cowslips occur and where they grow in close proximity, hybridise to form the False Oxslip. Specimens of Ipheion Uniflorum have been found recently on a roadside verge. Several rights of way cross the area, see OS MAP TL84/94. Access is also granted on a grace and favour basis to a disused railway line. This was con- structed along the course of a tribu- tary of Chad Brook. A covered drainage channel with inspection covers borders the track. This channel is full of water in the driest of summers and supports an established mini pond-life.
